title: Activity Theory-Based Co-Design Process for Musical Instrument Learning Language E-Services

context.prior_knowledge: Basic instrumental performance experience and proficiency with digital learning tools, foundational understanding of musical terminology
context.additional_context: Professionals in medical/legal/technical fields learning musical instrument performance to alleviate work-related stress. Learners apply problem-solving skills acquired in their work environments to music learning and participate in collaborative design using collaboration tools. Special emphasis on translating musical expressions into linguistic descriptions.

learning_goals: Learners can collaboratively design a prototype incorporating linguistic interaction elements for a musical instrument learning service using the Activity Theory framework.

Learners can use online collaboration tools like Figma or Miro to exchange real-time verbal feedback with two peers and a designer, producing a feedback document with five or more specific revision suggestions within one hour.
Learners can complete a learning portfolio utilizing instrument-playing recording and sharing features in a BYOD environment and verbally explain musical expressions.

resources: Musical Instrument Learning Software (GarageBand, MuseScore, etc.)

difficulty: Moderate - Standard complexity with some constraints
